text:
Being in the military is just
one way in which we serve.

Only 0.4% of the
population actually
volunteers to serve in the US.

African Americans have
always been part of the 0.4%.

And we've been doing it
since the Revolutionary

War and every conflict
until present day.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
I'm Hise Gibson.

I teach technology and
operations management
in the required curriculum.

My military career
spans 25 years.

I started as an army
helicopter pilot

and have commanded small and
large teams across the world

from Korea, Iraq,
and Afghanistan,

culminating in commanding in the
82nd Airborne Division at now

Fort Liberty, North Carolina,
prior to retiring as a colonel.

The military leaders that have
inspired me, there are many.

The first African
American graduate

of the United States
Military Academy,

Henry Ossian Flipper,
he went through his time

at the Academy in
the 1870s silenced,

meaning none of his
classmates talked to him.

He later became a commander in
the storied Buffalo Soldiers

in the 9th and 10th Cavalry and
then worked in the government.

This perseverance,
his determination,

and his duty to country created
my ability to go to West Point.

The first African American woman
is Pat Locke, class of 1980,

an amazing individual, helping
many people get into the United

States Military Academy and
other Service academies.

Military leaders
like Colin Powell,

the first African American
chairman of the Joint Chiefs

of Staff, he inspired me
to think about education

and think about how to
leverage my military training
outside of a military context.

If we think about what happened
in the Civil Rights movement,

it wasn't necessarily just
a bunch of people showing up
doing things.

There was a lot of structure,
processes, coordination that
utilized military training.

Key leaders like Martin Luther
King, Jr. or a young John Lewis
didn't have military training.

But the people who
supported these initiatives

along the side,
a lot of them had

been in the military,
understood how to organize,

to help support the
vision of those leaders

to ensure everyone had
the same civil rights.

I truly believe
that service is key,

and there's consistency in this
portion of the populace that

not only serves in the military,
but then translates to serve us

in many other areas, many
other industries that

create massive amount
of value for our nation.

Service is a cornerstone
to why the group that
was brought here--
didn't show up here--

still decide every day to wake
up, put on boots and a uniform,

and stand at the edge,
carrying our load

for the service of the
nation that we hold dear.
